content:
Let try two things:


If you recently changed your account settings, the Sent folder path in Account Settings -> Copies & Folders might not match your mail server’s folder name. (Example: Server uses 'Sent Items' but Thunderbird is still looking for Sent.)

OR

On IMAP accounts, if the Sent folder is not subscribed, Thunderbird can’t save to it. Check by right-clicking the account name → Subscribe and make sure the Sent folder is ticked.
creator: Thundamike

content:
It sounds like Thunderbird might be applying a filter or view setting that hides read emails unless they’re starred. You can try this:

In the folder, click on the filter drop-down (usually says “Unread”) and change it to “All.”

Check “View → Sort by” to ensure messages aren’t being grouped or hidden.

If that doesn’t work, back up your profile and try “Properties → Repair Folder” again to re-index.

Sometimes in tech (just like in life), the information is right there—it’s just hidden until we look at it from the right angle. It’s a bit like the way surah yaseen reminds us that clarity comes when we take the time to truly understand what’s in front of us. Visit: www.Suraheyaseen.com
creator: jawadulhassan1810

content:
If you're using Bitdefender antivirus, it might be caused by that. Note that disabling only Bitdefender Antispam will not help. Try this, which may or may not work:

Open Bitdefender 

- go to Protection > Online Threat Prevention > toggle off the 'Encrypted web scan' setting

New messages downloaded after that will hopefully be OK. However, old messages already downloaded to Thunderbird cannot be fixed. If old messages are still on your pop server, you can try downloading them again.

If you're using another antivirus, try disabling it and see what happens.
creator: siffemoz

content: This may work: click account settings and then server settings and tick the box to always request authentication

content: If you are being prompted for a password, that indicates that any prior password is not working. You can locate the password (if any) stored in thunderbird at settings>privacy&security. Otherwise, you need to contact your email provider for a new password.

content:
Export the Kaspersky root certificate from your Kaspersky installation:

Open Kaspersky → Settings → Additional → Network → Manage certificates → Export.

In Thunderbird, go to Settings → Privacy & Security → Certificates → Manage Certificates.

Import the Kaspersky root certificate and mark it as trusted for identifying websites and email users.

Restart Thunderbird.
creator: Thundamike

content: This sounds like it’s caused by the way Kaspersky Security Center handles certificate scanning. Thunderbird is just reacting when it sees a new certificate. You’ll probably get the best help by checking Kaspersky’s support or documentation on importing their root certificate into Thunderbird.
creator: Thundamike

content: If you have forgotten the password, you probably need to contact email provider for a new one. That is, if you are being prompted for a password, that indicates any password stored in Thunderbird is not working. When you click settings>privacy&security, the password being requested there is your WINDOWS password - the one you enter when you boot the PC.
creator: davidsk

content: If you are trying to view saved passwords and are unable to get past the "Primary Password" prompt. Try to remember your old master password. The Primpary password in Thunderbird is a local security measure and cannot be bypassed without knowing it. If you don’t have that but still control your email account, resetting the account password via the provider is the fastest route.
creator: Thundamike

content: As you indicated- '...when the laptop is shut down.' - use a Windows password to keep the PC from being accessed. If the laptop is shared, the set up separate Windows accounts for each. There are software products that allow putting passwords on folders, or you could encrypt the mail with this tip (which I have not used): https://www.wikihow.com/Protect-Folders-With-Passwords
creator: davidsk

content: thanks, aware of all that. The case is a single family account being used by several persons. It seems to be very difficult to have single mails encoded / protected. Mailvelope does this very effectively and reliably, but will be discontinued - either as such or on the Web.de platform. Proton offers something, but that does not work within Proton, only from Proton to other mailing platforms (which is somewhat weird) and does not really resolve the problem. Robert
creator: lonely-ryder

content: Your other option is to create separate profiles for each person. Then, you can use password software or encryption to protect each persons profile and use the profile manager to start thunderbird. Thunderbird itself cannot do what you want.

content:
I'm presuming you are talking about emails you have started to compose, but not finished, so you saved them as a Draft.

Those emails will be in the 'Drafts' folder. Select 'Drafts' folder. Select the relevant email, so you see the contents in the Message Pane, just below the header section, it should sau 'this is a draft message' and on the right side should be an 'Edit' button - click on it and it will open in a new Write window.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
If you are talking about emails you have received and you may want to edit eg: the Subject then that would have used an addon. You need to use the addon version which works in the version of Thunderbird which you are using. Please note all addon extensions are maintained and are the sole responsibility of the author - they are not maintained by Thunderbird.

Perhaps you used : Edit Email Subject: https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/edit-email-subject/

Header Tools lite https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/header-tools-lite
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
What version of Thunderbird are you using ? Is the BT account POP or IMAP ?

Try this:

  • Right click on Inbox folder and select 'Properties'
  • click on 'Repair Folder'
  • Click on 'OK'
creator: Toad-Hall
